Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Identifying Plastic Responses in Human Skeletal Tissues through a Sensitive Developmental Windows Framework

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration: Environmental factors exert considerable influence over processes of growth and development, and stress experienced in early life can have long-term consequences for health and mortality risk. It is therefore critical to understand when individuals are most vulnerable to stress exposures. Sensitive developmental windows (SDW) are periods in early life when energy needs are high, and developing tissues exhibit greater plasticity in response to stress. This doctoral dissertation project will examine evidence of plasticity in the human skeletal system using a SDW framework, in order to better understand how the timing of stress exposures in early life influence patterns of disease susceptibility and mortality risk over the lifespan. The intellectual impacts of this project will be the production of a novel framework in which to more clearly define the relationship between early life environments, biology, and health outcomes across the lifespan. Insights derived from this project about the lifetime impacts of developmental stress may inform research in human development and public health. The project will also facilitate training of undergraduate and graduate students in non-destructive methods of skeletal analysis that are broadly applicable across modern, historical, and archaeological contexts. <br/><br/>This project will improve existing methods of identifying and interpreting evidence of plasticity in the skeletal system by examining a set of asymmetries in skeletal elements that capture an extended period of early child development. Evidence for plasticity will be measured through the SDW framework by calculating asymmetry indices in three skeletal samples that represent human populations engaged in different modes of subsistence, social organization, and diet (early farmers, prehistoric agriculturalists, and historic preindustrialists). These asymmetry indices will be compared across populations and assessed using childhood mortality rates, age-at-death and adult stature as covariates, so that the impact of plasticity on mortality risk over the lifespan can be evaluated. The methodology employed in this project involves non-destructive analysis of skeletal elements, providing an accessible approach to examining plasticity.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report: NSF Award #2018997

Project Title: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Identifying Plastic Responses in Human Skeletal Tissues through a Sensitive Developmental Windows Framework

PI: James T. Watson, Co-PI: Cait B. McPherson

The primary goal of this project was to develop a novel methodological framework for identifying and interpreting evidence of developmental plasticity in the skeletal system, utilizing the sensitive developmental windows (SDWs) concept to link evidence of developmental stress embodied in hard tissue with adult phenotypic outcomes. The Developmental Origins of Health and Disease (DOHaD) hypothesis posits that phenotypic-environmental interactions in early life?in particular, exposure to early life stress?may modify risks to health and mortality throughout the life span. Throughout the course of development, biological systems exhibit varying degrees of sensitivity to environmental signals, which may provide critical information about short and long-term challenges to survival. Consequently, the timing of a signal may strongly impact whether it produces a phenotypic response. SDWs are periods of increased susceptibility to environmental feedback relative to other stages in development. An organism and its biological systems may exhibit multiple SDWs within a particular life history stage, each of which represents an opportunity for phenotypic adjustment. Thus, signals of environmental adversity may be more likely to impact development within SDWs, with potential consequences for health and wellbeing.

The interpretive framework developed as a result of this project extends existing bioarchaeological approaches informed by DOHaD by 1) examining evidence of stress in skeletal elements that are sensitized to environmental feedback at different stages in the developmental lifecycle, and 2) correlating artifacts of developmental stress with downstream phenotypic outcomes and indicators of fitness. By prioritizing the timing of stress events within and across life history phases, periods of heightened sensitivity to stress can be identified, along with potential life history trade-offs involving modifications to growth trajectories and heightened mortality risk in response to early life adversity. Due to its use of multiple skeletal and dental biomarkers, this approach has the potential to facilitate DOHaD studies in a broader variety of study populations, including imperfectly preserved archaeological samples. It is also applicable to a variety of research contexts involving skeletal material, to include forensic, public health, and biomedical studies.

To test the SDW framework, the Co-PI examined relationships between developmental stress, estimated stature and mortality risk in the Turkey Creek Pueblo (TCP) skeletal collection. The TCP collection represents a 13th century Ancestral Puebloan population, a largely egalitarian society of maize agriculturalists who lived in an ecologically rich region of what is now east-central Arizona. The Co-PI collected data on three key vertebral measures (anterior-posterior and transverse vertebral neural canal diameters, and vertebral body height), each representing stress experienced within overlapping periods of development, from all available vertebrae within the C3-L5 sequence. Correlations between these measures, estimated stature, and age at death were examined in order to identify periods of heightened sensitivity to stress, in which potential trade-offs involving reductions in stature and heightened mortality risk were initiated.

The results of this study suggest that the SDW model has considerable utility in studies of developmental stress within skeletal biology, and was successfully used by the Co-PI and PI to identify potential life history trade-offs involving growth and mortality risk in an archaeological sample. In the TCP population, numerous correlations were identified between small VNC measures, estimated stature, and estimated age at death. However, no correlations were identified between small stature and earlier age at death. The results of this project suggest that in environments characterized by chronic stress: 1) proximate signals of nutritional stress may have a stronger influence on growth potential than signals of early life stress; and 2) reduced stature may represent strategic reallocation of energetic resources in response to environmental adversity. However, early life stress may influence trade-offs involving early life resilience and heightened mortality risk in adulthood. Furthermore, the results of this study suggest that VNC measures are best utilized as part of a multi-marker model, since they differentially embody developmental stress.

As a result of this project, the Co-PI has published an article summarizing the SDW framework (https://doi.org/10.1002/ajpa.24338), its applications within the realm of skeletal biology, and its potential to facilitate collaborative projects within human biology. A second article, which considers archaeological and paleoanthropological applications of the model, has been accepted for publication. The Co-PI has also prepared a third article for publication, summarizing the results of the TCP analysis, and is developing a presentation for the 2023 American Association of Biological Anthropologists conference. In addition, the Co-PI also conducted a full osteological analysis of the TCP skeletal collection for the Arizona State Museum, under the supervision of the PI. The analysis and associated reports will facilitate the eventual repatriation of the TCP skeletal collection, consistent with the Native American Graves Protection and Repatriation Act (NAGPRA).
